column1: No officials at the AIG Tokyo office or GE Edison were immediately available to comment on the reports.
column2: Tokyo PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19753773" id="Pl-15" latLong="35.685°N 139.751°E" predicative="true" state="13" type="PPLC"

column1: GE Edison would be AIG's third life insurance unit in Japan following Alico Japan and AIG Star life Insurance Co.
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-9" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The acquisition of GE Edison is expected to boost AIG's annual life insurance premium revenue in Japan to about 1.1 trillion yen, ranking it sixth in the Japanese life insurance business.
column2: Japanese PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-10" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-9" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Israel  hands over Rafah  border crossing  to Palestinians ATTENTION -
column2: crossing PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-71" mod="BORDER" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Rafah PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202813" id="Pl-16" latLong="31.284°N 34.251°E" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-15" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: GAZA CITY , June 30 (AFP) Palestinian security forces returned Monday to the positions they held in the Gaza Strip before the outbreak of the 33-month Palestinian uprising as Israel removed all major checkpoints in the coastal territory , a Palestinian security source said.
column2: ,Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"

column1: Police officers took up their positions across the Gaza Strip , enjoying a freedom of movement they have not known since the intifada exploded in September 2000, the source said.

Palestinian police have taken over all the posts and positions they held before September 28, 2000.	 ,Palestinian PLACE country=PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"
It is the first time they have had freedom of movement with cars and weapons since the start of the intifada," the source said.
The move marked a huge step forward in carrying out the US -backed Middle East "roadmap", which aims to end the months of bloodshed and create a lasting peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
column2: ,US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-42" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",road PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-80" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"

column1: Following the withdrawal of Israeli troops from the northern town of Beit Hanoun late Sunday, police took up positions there and in the neighbouring town of Beit Lahiya , he said.
column2: ,Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Israeli PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="P-386" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Beit Lahiya PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202857" id="Pl-45" latLong="31.550°N 34.500°E" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Beit Hanoun PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-44" mod="N" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: They also deployed along the border with Israel .
column2: ,Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The handover is a credibility test for the Palestinian Authority, which must show it means business when it comes to reining in hardline groups plotting attacks on the Jewish state .
column2: ,state PLACE country="IL" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-46" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"

column1: In another first in the almost three-year intifada, the Israeli army allowed Palestinians free circulation on the trans- Gaza highway as troops abandoned three major checkpoints across the coastal territory . Traffic was flowing freely through the Netzarim junction , SIGNAL id="S-1" just south SIGNAL of Gaza City , the Kissufim junction SIGNAL id="S-6" by SIGNAL Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip , and the Guest House junction SIGNAL id="S-2" just south SIGNAL of Deir al-Balah after the army withdrew.
column2: ,highway PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-67" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Deir al-Balah PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-53" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Israeli PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="P-386" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Netzarim PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202823" id="Pl-62" latLong="31.483°N 34.450°E" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Kissufim PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219532" id="Pl-57" latLong="31.374°N 34.399°E" predicative="true" state="D" type="PPL",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN",Guest House PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-65" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: The three military checkpoints on the highway , which runs the entire length of the Gaza Strip , had transformed the trip from north SIGNAL id="S-5" to SIGNAL south , ordinarily a 30-minute ride, into a grinding two or three-hour ordeal and came to symbolise the horrors of occupation.
column2: ,highway PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-67" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD"

column1: Israel has implemented most of the agreement except for a few issues, the source said, pointing out that Israel had still not removed two military observation posts at the Kissufim junction and the Guest House junction .
column2: ,Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Kissufim PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219532" id="Pl-57" latLong="31.374°N 34.399°E" predicative="true" state="D" type="PPL",Guest House PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-65" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: Although there was free movement along the trans- Gaza highway , several other roads remained temporarily closed, he said.
column2: ,highway PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-67" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",road PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-80" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD"

column1: The Karni - Netzarim road , which runs east-to-west across the route , was still closed as was the section of the highway passing SIGNAL id="S-7" close by SIGNAL Kfar Darom settlement, SIGNAL id="S-3" just south SIGNAL of the Guest House junction , he said, adding both were likely to be opened in the coming weeks.
column2: ,highway PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-67" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Kfar Darom PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-64" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",road PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-80" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Netzarim PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202823" id="Pl-62" latLong="31.483°N 34.450°E" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",section PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-66" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Karni PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-60" state="PS-GZ",route PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-85" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Guest House PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-65" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: Another road , leading from the southern border town of Rafah SIGNAL id="S-4" to SIGNAL Khan Yunis , would be opened within 10 days, he said.
column2: ,road PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-80" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Khan Yunis PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202835" id="Pl-68" latLong="31.344°N 34.303°E" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Rafah PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202813" id="Pl-40" latLong="31.284°N 34.251°E" mod="BORDER" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: Adressing Palestinian complaints, an Israeli military source confirmed troops had installed a gate at the Netzarim crossing and at the southern Guest House junction but said that they were only there for when Jewish settlers needed to use the road .
column2: ,crossing PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-76" mod="BORDER" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",road PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-80" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Israeli PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="P-386" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Netzarim PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202823" id="Pl-62" latLong="31.483°N 34.450°E" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN",Guest House PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" id="Pl-65" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: A ban on Palestinian men under the age of 35 being allowed to move freely was still in force but that was expected to be lifted later on Monday or early Tuesday.
column2: ,Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"

column1: The army also handed over control of Rafah border crossing between the Gaza Strip and Egypt to the Palestinians, security sources said.
column2: ,crossing PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-76" mod="BORDER" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Egypt PLACE country="EG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19706664" id="Pl-82" latLong="27.000°N 30.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN",Rafah PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202813" id="Pl-40" latLong="31.284°N 34.251°E" mod="BORDER" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL"

column1: Six Palestinian police officers were allowed to return to the Palestinian section of the border crossing , which had been taken over by Israeli troops shortly after the start of the uprising.
column2: ,crossing PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-76" mod="BORDER" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Israeli PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="P-386" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",section PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-66" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"

column1: Under the 1993 Oslo accords, which granted a measure of autonomy to the Palestinians, the Rafah border crossing with Egypt was to be jointly managed by both Israel and the Palestinians, although Israel had final control over the zone .
column2: ,crossing PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-76" mod="BORDER" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Egypt PLACE country="EG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19706664" id="Pl-82" latLong="27.000°N 30.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN",Rafah PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19202813" id="Pl-40" latLong="31.284°N 34.251°E" mod="BORDER" predicative="true" state="PS-GZ" type="PPL",Oslo PLACE country="NO" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19726163" id="Pl-83" latLong="59.917°N 10.750°E" predicative="true" state="NO-03" type="PPL"

column1: Although the crossing has, in principle, been open for movement between the two territories -- while being frequently closed by Israeli for reasons rarely explained -- the Palestinian section has been manned by Israel for more than two years.
column2: ,crossing PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-76" mod="BORDER" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Israel PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="Pl-14" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",Israeli PLACE country="IL" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19219725" id="P-386" latLong="31.500°N 34.750°E" type="COUNTRY",section PLACE country="PS" form="NOM" id="Pl-66" state="PS-GZ" type="ROAD",Palestinian PLACE country="PS" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:208674239" id="Pl-28" predicative="true" type="RGN"

column1: Police fire tear gas as Nigerian  strike enters day two
column2: Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-3" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Nigerian police fired tear gas Tuesday to disperse protesters gathering outside the government's main administrative offices on the second day of a nationwide general strike.
column2: Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-4" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: A large contingent of riot police appeared determined to prevent a protest building up outside the Federal Secretariat offices , as one had on Monday when trade union activists barricaded the entrance with parked cars.
As on Monday, police dispersed the demonstrators with a volley of teargas, an AFP reporter saw.
Meanwhile, in the commercial capital Lagos union officials said that protesting students had begun building burning barricades around the Lagos State University Campus .
column2: Lagos PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17982645" id="Pl-6" latLong="6.453°N 3.396°E" state="LA" type="PPL"

column1: Nigerian unions have launched a general strike in protest at a government decision to hike the price of petrol and diesel by 54 percent.
column2: Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-4" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Former Russian  aluminum baron convicted of trying to cover up murder
column2: Russian PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-1" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Former Russian aluminum baron Anatoly Bykov was convicted Tuesday of covering up the murder of a business rival and then immediately amnestied in court, Interfax reported.
column2: Russian PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-2" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Russia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-4" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Bykov had initially been charged with organizing the murder of Oleg Gubin in Siberia 's Krasnoyarsk region , which has seen several high-profile slayings allegedly linked to a fight for control of the area's vast mineral wealth.
column2: region PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-19" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL",Krasnoyarsk PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-11" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL",Siberia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16995911" id="Pl-16" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" state="NVS" type="RGN",Krasnoyarsk region PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-15" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL"

column1: The court changed the charge sheet against Bykov in the course of the trial.
He was sentenced to a one year prison term and then amnestied in court, the Interfax report said.
It was the second time Bykov was set free after a trial focusing on his links to assassination attempts against his Krasnoyarsk rivals.
column2: Krasnoyarsk PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-11" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL"

column1: A Moscow court last year upheld a six-and-a-half year suspended sentence for the attempted murder of another Bykov rival, Vilor Struganov, who had been a business partner of the aluminium baron.
column2: Moscow PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17039439" id="Pl-6" latLong="55.752°N 37.616°E" state="MOS" type="PPLC"

column1: Bykov was convicted of ordering a failed assasination attempt on September 29, 2000, against Struganov -- alias "Pasha the Strobe Light," who is described as one of the mafia chiefs of Krasnoyarsk .
column2: Krasnoyarsk PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-11" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL"

column1: Ex-boxer Bykov became one of the most powerful men in the Krasnoyarsk region in the 1990s when he took control of the aluminum giant KrAz.
column2: region PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-19" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL",Krasnoyarsk PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-11" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL",Krasnoyarsk region PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-15" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL"

column1: He was ousted as head of KrAZ -- Russia 's second largest aluminum smelter, which is now part of Oleg Deripaska's RusAl conglomerate -- shortly after falling foul of former Krasnoyarsk governor Alexander Lebed, who died in a helicopter crash in April 2002.
column2: Krasnoyarsk PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-11" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL",Russia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-4" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Bykov, who enjoyed tremendous popularity in the region despite his own alleged mafia ties, had supported Lebed's gubernatorial campaign.
column2: region PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-19" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL"

column1: But he fled to Hungary after Lebed turned on him and attempted to install his own associates as KrAZ directors, as part of a campaign to clean up business practices in the mineral-rich region . Extradited to Russia in 2000 on charges of money laundering and several murders, Bykov was released on August 24 2002.
column2: region PLACE country="RU" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17063317" id="Pl-19" latLong="58.000°N 93.000°E" state="KIA" type="CIVIL",Hungary PLACE country="HU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19143844" id="Pl-20" latLong="47.000°N 20.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Russia PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-4" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He said the charges were intended to force him to give up his 20-percent stake in KrAz.
Nigerian  police fire tear gas, beat journalists on day two of strike
column2: Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-1" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Nigerian police fired tear gas Tuesday to disperse strikers gathering outside the government's main administrative offices and assaulted three journalists covering the protests.
column2: Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-5" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: As a general strike called to protest a government decision to increase fuel prices by 54 percent entered its second day, protesters gathered in front of the Federal Secretariat building in Abuja .
column2: Abuja PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18002987" id="Pl-9" latLong="9.083°N 7.533°E" state="FC" type="PPLC"

column1: A first gathering of a few dozen people was dispersed by a volley of tear gas from riot police who arrived in 18 jeeps, but when labour leader Adams Oshiomhole arrived to address the strikers, hundreds of supporters gathered.
Police again fired tear gas and waded into the crowd, sending the strikers scattering for cover in the secretariat building itself.

A Nigerian photographer from the New York -based agency the Associated Press (AP), George Osodi, the labour editor of the Nigerian daily The Vanguard Funmi Komolafe and Vanguard reporter Rotimi Ajayi were beaten by police.
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:976772" id="Pl-11" latLong="40.714°N 74.006°W" state="NY" type="PPL",Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-5" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The AP photographer's camera was smashed and he was beaten with whips and rifle butts, leaving him badly bruised.

In the commercial capital Lagos , students were setting up barricades around their campus , while police played a cat-and-mouse game with protesters elsewhere in the city . Later Oshiomhole emerged from the secretariat building SIGNAL id="S-1" in SIGNAL Abuja and once more addressed supporters, calling on them to show restraint.
column2: Lagos PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17982645" id="Pl-10" latLong="6.453°N 3.396°E" state="LA" type="PPL",Abuja PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18002987" id="Pl-9" latLong="9.083°N 7.533°E" state="FC" type="PPLC",city PLACE country="NG" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17982645" id="Pl-12" latLong="6.453°N 3.396°E" state="LA" type="PPL"

column1: I want to assure you that I'm safe, he said.

There is no peace in life without struggle.	
Every job has its own hazards.	
My plea is that Nigerian workers should be peaceful, but don't go to work until these issues are resolved."
column2: Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-5" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: After Oshiomhole drove off, protesters began to disperse quietly and the police scaled down their presence.
Meanwhile there were conflicting reports that protesters had been shot dead by security forces on Monday.
Asked by AFP to confirm press and television reports that between two and eight people had been shot, national police spokesman Chris Olakpe had initially said: "It was four."
But he later rang back to deny the reports.
I have checked our records and found that 88 people were arrested nationwide, but I have no record of people shot, he said.
According to the state -owned Daily Times eight people were killed in protests in Abuja on Monday, the first day of a general strike.
column2: Abuja PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18002987" id="Pl-9" latLong="9.083°N 7.533°E" state="FC" type="PPLC",state PLACE country="NG" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:18002985" id="Pl-13" latLong="8.833°N 7.167°E" state="FC" type="CIVIL"

column1: Another daily, The Champion, put the number at two.
Both papers said that security forces, either police or army, had shot at protesters.
An army spokesman told AFP he had no knowledge of the incident.
Witnesses say Bali  suspect asked if they were willing to be suicide
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-5" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN"

column1: DENPASAR , Indonesia , July 2 (AFP) Three witnesses said Wednesday that alleged Bali bombing mastermind Imam Samudra had asked them if they were willing to become suicide bombers.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN",Indonesia PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17320538" id="Pl-4" latLong="5.000°S 120.000°E" type="COUNTRY",DENPASAR PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17323228" id="Pl-1" latLong="8.650°S 115.217°E" state="BA" type="PPLA"

column1: They were testifying in the trial of Samudra, 33, who is accused of plotting the terror bombing of two Bali nightspots in an attack that killed 202 people on this Indonesian resort island last October.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN",Indonesian PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17320538" id="Pl-3" latLong="5.000°S 120.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Indonesia PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17320538" id="Pl-4" latLong="5.000°S 120.000°E" type="COUNTRY",island PLACE country="ID" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-13" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN"

column1: Two of the witnesses said they had only discussed with Samudra plans to help Muslims in the religiously divided Ambon and Poso regions and had no knowledge about any plans to stage bombings in Bali . "I was hesitant.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN",Poso PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" id="Pl-19" type="PPL",Ambon PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17329726" id="Pl-17" latLong="3.717°S 128.200°E" state="MA" type="PPLA"

column1: Shahid (martyrdom) bombing?
In Indonesia ?" asked Abdul Rauf.
column2: Indonesia PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17320538" id="Pl-4" latLong="5.000°S 120.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Another witness, Junaedi, alias Amin, testified that Samudra once asked him: "Are you ready to carry a martyr's bomb?"
Junaedi, an accomplice in a robbery to help fund the bombings, said he did not reply.

Police accused regional terror group Jemaah Islamiyah (JI), which is believed linked to al-Qaeda, of staging the bombing of nightspots crowded with Western holidaymakers to avenge perceived injustices against Muslims worldwide.
Rauf is on trial for robbing a jewellery shop in Banten to fund the Bali bombings.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN",Banten PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" id="Pl-20" type="PPL"

column1: Like Samudra, he has been described as a computer expert.
One of Rauf's accomplices in the robbery, Andri Oktavia, said he was "doubtful" about the possibility of staging a suicide attack.
It was only Iqbal who expressed readiness, Oktavia told judges.
Prosecutors say Iqbal detonated an explosives-stuffed vest he was wearing inside Paddy's Bar .
Seconds later a man called Arnasan detonated a huge van bomb outside the nearby Sari Club .
Arnasan died but it was unclear if he intended to be a suicide bomber.
The disclosure that at least one suicide bomber was involved in the Bali attack heightened concern among security forces in Southeast Asia , where such tactics were previously unknown.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN"

column1: Rauf and Oktavia said they gave the stolen gold bars from the jewellery store to Samudra and said the proceeds from the sale were supposed to be used for jihad (holy war or struggle) to help Muslims in Ambon and Poso.
column2: Poso PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" id="Pl-19" type="PPL",Ambon PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17329726" id="Pl-17" latLong="3.717°S 128.200°E" state="MA" type="PPLA"

column1:
We trusted him.	
We were determined to help oppressed Muslims in Ambon and Poso , Oktavia said.
column2: Poso PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" id="Pl-19" type="PPL",Ambon PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17329726" id="Pl-17" latLong="3.717°S 128.200°E" state="MA" type="PPLA"

column1: Ambon and Poso have been the scene of clashes between Muslims and Christians, leaving thousands dead and a trail of destruction.
column2: Poso PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" id="Pl-19" type="PPL",Ambon PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17329726" id="Pl-17" latLong="3.717°S 128.200°E" state="MA" type="PPLA"

column1: Both Rauf and Oktavia said they used three handguns lent to them by Samudra in the robbery.
Samudra, who police say has admitted ordering the Bali attack, denied that he conspired with the witnesses to rob the jewellery shop.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN"

column1:
They did not say that the guns were to be used in a robbery.	
As far as I knew they borrowed them for jihad, Samudra told the court.
If I had known they were to be used in a robbery I wouldn't have lent them, he said, adding that robberies were forbidden in Islam.
Oktavia said at first he thought the robbery was justified.

I was thinking that maybe it was okay to rob Chinese.	
They are rich while most people in Banten are very poor.	Banten PLACE country=ID" form="NAM" id="Pl-20" type="PPL"
Besides... I was not going to use the money myself.
It was for oppressed people," he said.
But after thinking it over, it was somewhat wrong, he said.
Rauf and Oktavia said Samudra took them to Bali before the bombings but they did not know why.
column2: Bali PLACE country="ID" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17328623" id="Pl-12" latLong="8.333°S 115.000°E" state="BA" type="RGN"

column1: Rauf said Samudra allowed them to return and told him: "You can always wage jihad anywhere."
Junaedi said Samudra once showed him Paddy's and the Sari Club . "He told me to take note, this is a place where white people gather, and take note of the streets here," Junaedi testified.
The trial was adjourned until Thursday.
Samudra and other key suspects face death if convicted.
Passenger stabbed with fork on Thai  Airways flight into Sydney
column2: Thai PLACE country="TH" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16743915" id="Pl-1" latLong="15.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: SYDNEY , July 16 (AFP) An airline passenger was stabbed in the neck during a Thai Airways flight from Bangkok to Sydney Wednesday, Australian Federal Police said.
column2: Bangkok PLACE country="TH" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16749917" id="Pl-4" latLong="13.750°N 100.517°E" state="10" type="PPLC",Thai PLACE country="TH" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16743915" id="Pl-3" latLong="15.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",SYDNEY PLACE country="AU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18396865" id="Pl-5" latLong="33.883°S 151.217°E" state="NSW" type="PPLA",Sydney PLACE country="AU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18396865" id="Pl-7" latLong="33.883°S 151.217°E" state="NSW" type="PPLA"

column1: A 50-year-old man was stabbed in the head and neck with a fork in what is believed to have been an argument over seating arrangements.

The man, described by the airline as a Vietnamese -born Sydney resident, was taken to hospital after the plane touched down at 6:30 am (2030 GMT Tuesday) but police said his injuries were not life-threatening.
column2: Vietnamese PLACE country="VN" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16266660" id="Pl-10" latLong="16.167°N 107.833°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",Sydney PLACE country="AU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18396865" id="Pl-7" latLong="33.883°S 151.217°E" state="NSW" type="PPLA"

column1: A 22-year-old man from Sydney was being questioned by police.
column2: Sydney PLACE country="AU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18396865" id="Pl-7" latLong="33.883°S 151.217°E" state="NSW" type="PPLA"

column1: Thai Airways said the cabin report of flight TG991 showed two passengers were involved in an argument after dinner.
column2: Thai PLACE country="TH" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16743915" id="Pl-3" latLong="15.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1:
One male passenger was apparently attacked with a fork.	
First aid treatment was given to the injured passenger and the attacker was restrained and put at the rear of the aircraft, the airline said in a statement.
The Australian government has announced plans to increase airline security after a number of incidents in recent months.
Last month a Sydney man was arrested for brandishing a knife on board a Virgin Blue flight from Sydney to Cairns .
column2: Sydney PLACE country="AU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18396865" id="Pl-7" latLong="33.883°S 151.217°E" state="NSW" type="PPLA"

column1: Uzbek  executions a "grave breach:" UN committee
column2: Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-1" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: TASHKENT , July 25 (AFP) The United Nations Human Rights Committee on Friday strongly criticised Uzbekistan 's execution of six people whose cases were awaiting the committee's consideration.
column2: Uzbekistan PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-8" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY",TASHKENT PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420628" id="Pl-10" latLong="41.317°N 69.250°E" state="TK" type="PPLC",Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-9" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The Geneva -based committee said it "deplored" the Central Asian ex-Soviet republic's recent execution of Muzaffar Mirzaev, Shukrat Andasbaev, Ulugbek Eshov, Ilkhon Babadzhanov, Maksud Ismailov and Azamat Uteev.
column2: Geneva PLACE country="CH" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17447849" id="Pl-11" latLong="46.200°N 6.167°E" state="GE" type="PPLA"

column1: The committee urged Uzbekistan to refrain from executing other prisoners whose appeals to the committee are pending and "reminded" Uzbekistan "that it amounts to a grave breach (of UN protocol) to execute an individual whose case is pending," the statement said.
column2: Uzbekistan PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-8" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-9" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In a statement, the acting High Commissioner for Human Rights Bertrand Ramcharan said he deeply regretted the executions.

These executions render futile (the) review by the Human Rights Committee of these cases, which amount to a grave breach of Uzbekistan 's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the statement said.
column2: Uzbekistan PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-8" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-9" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In early July Amnesty International highlighted the case of Mirzaev, 29, who it said had been executed secretly in June "despite allegations that he was mentally ill."

Friday's statement by the UN human rights committee follows raised international attention to human rights abuses by Uzbekistan , which under hardline President Islam Karimov has been a key supporter of US -led anti-terrorism efforts centred on neighbouring Afghanistan .
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-14" type="COUNTRY",Uzbekistan PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-8" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Afghanistan PLACE country="AF" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420628" id="Pl-13" latLong="33.000°N 65.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-9" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Visiting Uzbekistan in December, the United Nations' rapporteur on torture Theo van Boven said that torture by the Uzbek security forces appeared to be "systematic".
column2: Uzbekistan PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-8" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-9" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Critics have charged that Karimov's rule may actually encourage Muslims to carry out extremist acts as there is virtually no legal way for them to express dissent.
Activists put the number of political and religious prisoners in Uzbekistan as high as 6,500.
column2: Uzbekistan PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-8" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Uzbek PLACE country="UZ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17420359" id="Pl-9" latLong="41.000°N 64.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Taylor meets west African  envoys on exile call
Liberia 's embattled president, Charles Taylor, began meeting Saturday with a west African ministerial delegation which has travelled to Monrovia to demand he step down and head into exile.
column2: Liberia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-8" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY",Monrovia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-5" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" mod="CENTRAL" state="MO" type="PPLC"

column1: Taylor and his vice-president Moses Blah met with a team led by Mohamed ibn Chambas, executive secretary of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), at the president's official residence in the besieged city .
column2: city PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-24" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" state="MO" type="PPLC"

column1: The Liberian leader had been expected to meet the ECOWAS party on Friday, but failed to turn up, annoying some members of the delegation.
column2: Liberian PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-9" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY",Liberia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-8" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Arriving at the meeting, Taylor angrily denied that he had tried to avoid the envoys.
I'm not running away, he said, accusing the media of lying about his absence the previous day.

Aides claimed Taylor had travelled to the port city of Buchanan , a short distance south of the capital , one of the frontlines in his war with two rebel armies who control four fifths of the country .
column2: Buchanan PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17869263" id="Pl-18" latLong="5.881°N 10.047°W" state="GB" type="PPL",capital PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-12" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" state="MO" type="PPLC",city PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-24" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" state="MO" type="PPLC",country PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-10" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The ECOWAS delegation included Ghana 's Foreign Minister Addo Akufo Addo, the Nigerian minister for cooperation and integration Lawan Gana Guba and the Togolese defense minister General Assani Tidjani.
column2: Ghana PLACE country="GH" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17926607" id="Pl-19" latLong="8.000°N 2.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Nigeria PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-21" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-22" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Togolese PLACE country="TG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18500437" id="Pl-23" latLong="8.000°N 1.167°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Nigeria has offered Taylor political asylum if he agrees to resign his post and allow international mediators to broker an agreement to end Liberia 's latest four-year bout of civil war.
column2: Nigeria PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-21" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Liberia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-8" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: A 1,500-strong advance guard of Nigerian peacekeepers is due to start arriving in Monrovia on Monday, and ECOWAS has given Taylor an ultimatum that he must leave office within three days of the soldiers' arrival.
column2: Nigeria PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-21" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Nigerian PLACE country="NG" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17979109" id="Pl-22" latLong="10.000°N 8.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Monrovia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-5" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" mod="CENTRAL" state="MO" type="PPLC"

column1: But even as the warlord-turned-president arrived at his official residence , intense fighting was continuing on the frontline in the capital , an AFP reporter at the scene said.
column2: capital PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-12" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" state="MO" type="PPLC"

column1: Liberian government forces fought their way across two frontline bridges in the capital Monrovia in what commanders said was an offensive aimed a recapturing the city 's rebel-held port . Loyalist troops crossed the two key bridges , the site of a two-week standoff with rebels, under a heavy barrage of rocket and mortar fire and entered Via Town , a city district separating central Monrovia from the port area . Several houses could be seen burning in Via Town as the fighting raged.
column2: Via Town PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:20120641" id="Pl-27" latLong="6.631°N 10.250°W" state="MO" type="PPL",city district PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:20120641" id="Pl-26" latLong="6.631°N 10.250°W" state="MO" type="PPL",capital PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-12" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" state="MO" type="PPLC",Liberian PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-9" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY",city PLACE country="LR" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-24" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" state="MO" type="PPLC",Liberia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17866482" id="Pl-8" latLong="6.500°N 9.500°W" type="COUNTRY",port area PLACE country="NG" form="NOM" id="Pl-28" state="GB" type="RGN",Monrovia PLACE country="LR" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17865988" id="Pl-5" latLong="6.311°N 10.805°W" mod="CENTRAL" state="MO" type="PPLC"

column1: Government officers on the ground said the offensive was aimed at securing the port to allow west African peacekeepers to bring in men and equipment.
Silent struggle for control of Najaf  , Iraq  's Shiite power base by

column1: NAJAF , Iraq , Aug 3 (AFP) The holy city of Najaf , power base of Iraq 's Shiite Muslim majority, is locked in a silent battle between those prepared to cooperate with the US -led administration and those who champion resistance.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY",NAJAF PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897127" id="Pl-2" latLong="31.992°N 44.351°E" state="NA" type="PPL",Najaf PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897127" id="Pl-5" latLong="31.992°N 44.351°E" state="NA" type="PPL",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-9" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The struggle by supporters of firebrand cleric Moqtada Sadr to push the religious hierarchy into a more antagonistic approach towards the Americans has seen three attacks on mainstream clerics in the past two weeks, sources say.
column2: American PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-19" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Such crimes are aimed at provoking disturbances in the town , but the people have ignored them, said a son of Ayatollah Mohammad Said al-Hakim, one of Shiite Islam's top four clerics.
column2: town PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897127" id="Pl-18" latLong="31.992°N 44.351°E" state="NA" type="PPL"

column1: But these pressures "won't make the Hawza change its policy", Mohammad Hussein al-Hakim said, stressing that the hierarchy continued to favour talks as the best way of ending the US -led occupation.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY"

column1: However, Sadr, who is himself scion of an illustrious family of ayatollahs, has openly defied the hierarchy by condemning all contact with US forces.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-15" type="COUNTRY"

column1: During the mainly weekly prayers in the nearby town of Kufa Friday, he demanded the withdrawal of US troops.

column1: A theology student, Amjad al-Azari, was beaten with the butt of a rifle on Tuesday for refusing to drive armed men to Hakim junior's house , a source close to the Hawza said.
Similarly, last Sunday, Sheikh Dia al-Modhaffar, a relative of Ayatollah Hakim, was beaten black and blue in the street by unknown assailants.
Supporters of Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, another of Shiite Islam's leading clerics, have also been subject to attacks.
An official from his office, Ibrahim Layez, was admitted to hospital with multiple stab wounds two weeks ago, although he is now said to be out of danger.
These attacks have been accompanied by "death threats" against the ayatollahs, said Hakim junior.
Officially, no complaints have been filed, but the ayatollah's son blames those who see their only hope of power and influence in "chaos".
It must be an outsider, because the population is known for its allegiance to the Hawza and respect for it is sacrosanct in the town , he said.
column2: town PLACE country="IQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:16897127" id="Pl-18" latLong="31.992°N 44.351°E" state="NA" type="PPL"

column1: Instead, he pointed the finger at "certain blemishes on the name of Islam" who collude with the media, in a clear reference to Sadr, whose sermons are regularly featured on television.
But a spokesman for Sadr denied any role in the violence, dismissing the allegations as "prejudice".
Any attack against a member of the Hawza, be he a dignitary or a simple student, is unacceptable, said Sheikh Mustafa Yaqubi.
Yaqubi defended Sadr's opposition to the Americans, although he acknowledged it had little support among the tribes who still dominate the countryside.

column1: Equatorial Guinea  president pardons jailed political opponents
column2: Equatorial Guinea PLACE country="GQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-3" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Equatorial Guinea 's President Teodoro Obiang Nguema has provisionally pardoned 31 men jailed last year for plotting a coup, among them his chief political opponent, state radio and television said Sunday.
column2: Equatorial Guinea PLACE country="GQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-2" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Guinea PLACE country="GQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-8" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Placido Mico Abogo, 39, secretary general of the main opposition party, the Convergence for Social Democracy (CPDS), was serving two years and eight months after being sentenced in June 2002 for alleged complicity in a plot against the president.
He was originally sentenced to 14 years and eight months but the term was later reduced.
Thirty other prisoners, 18 political opponents and 12 military officers, also sentenced in June 2002, have also been pardoned.
News of the pardons came on the eve of celebrations marking the 24th anniversary of Obiang Nguema's seizing of power in the former central African Spanish colony in a coup.
column2: Spanish PLACE country="ES" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19596523" id="Pl-5" latLong="40.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The pardon "is granted to the indicted persons on condition that they do not again commit the crimes or errors under amnesty for a period of 10 years," according to a decree read on official media.
Placido Mico Abogo was found guilty with 67 other defendants, civilian and military, for taking part in a plot whose existence they denied.

The two alleged ringleaders, Felipe Ondo Obiang, who held ministerial office several times and was speaker of the parliament, and former finance minister Guillermo Nguema Ela, will not benefit from the amnesty.
They are leaders of the banned Republican Democratic Force (FDR) opposition party and are serving sentences of 20 and 14 years respectively.
A further 30 people found guilty were pardoned in October last year on the occasion of the national holiday.
column2: national PLACE country="GQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-6" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Three others died in hospital from injuries allegedly received during their detention and questioning.
The trial of more than 140 people began on May 23, 2002 after the defendants, who included opposition leaders, a score of military men and four women, had been rounded up by security forces in March.
Seventy-six were acquitted.
It was held in the disused Narsil cinema , where the country 's first president Francisco Macias Nguema was tried and sentenced to death after his overthrow by the current head of state, his nephew.
column2: country PLACE country="GQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-9" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Defence lawyers denounced the trial as being politically motivated and directly targetting opposition leaders, particularly the heads of the FDR.
When the trial opened, Ondo Obiang limped into court and many of the accused had visible difficulty raising their right hand for the oath of truth.
Five defendants who gave evidence at the start of the trial all said confessions had been extracted from them by torture.
Former UN special rapporteur in Guinea , Gustavo Gallon, said in a report from the country that torture was used there as a "normal means of investigation".
column2: Guinea PLACE country="GQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-8" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY",country PLACE country="GQ" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17935106" id="Pl-9" latLong="2.000°N 10.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Japanese  camera makers Konica, Minolta merge

column1: Struggling Konica and Minolta merged Tuesday to form Konica Minolta Holdings Inc., Japan 's fourth-largest camera and office equipment maker, a company spokesman said.
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-4" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Minolta shares, which were delisted in late July, will be exchanged for 0.
621 Konica shares, which were to take the name of the holding company Tuesday, a company spokesman said.
Minolta Co. Ltd. will be dissolved as a company by October 1.
We plan to release new digital cameras and other products with the new brand some time next year, said spokesman Katsuyuki Sakai.
The merger of the camera and office equipment makers, announced in January, was made "in order to survive amidst today's global competition", the new company said in a release Tuesday.
The company plans to cut 4,000 jobs from the combined workforce of 38,500 and reduce overlaps in plants and stores by March 2006, it said.
Konica Corp., a camera and film maker, and Minolta Co. Ltd., a camera, copier and printer firm, have jointly developed and produced copiers since 2000.

In the year to March 2006, the new company is targeting an operating profit of 150 billion yen (1.3 billion dollars) on sales of 1.3 trillion yen, making it the fourth-ranked photographic equipment maker in Japan behind leader Canon, Fuji Photo Film and Ricoh.
column2: Japan PLACE country="JP" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19768770" id="Pl-4" latLong="36.000°N 138.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: They Refuse to Reason

2004-11-01T18:06:00 I wish I could have been at a Pub , or wherever these people convene, to see the reactions from all the Britons who read the Telegraph this morning (emphasis added): Britain 's gun laws are aimed at the wrong target, curbing and criminalising legal ownership while failing to tackle huge rises in shooting offences over the past few years, according to an international firearms legislation expert.
column2: ,Britain PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-3" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Prof Gary Mauser said that Britain was making the same mistake as Canada and Australia in focusing on legal owners - a section of the law-abiding community where gun crimes, such as the Dunblane massacre, were aberrations .
column2: ,Britain PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-3" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Canada PLACE country="CA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19437937" id="Pl-8" latLong="60.000°N 96.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Dunblane PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17405158" id="Pl-10" latLong="56.200°N 3.967°W" predicative="true" state="BG-SCT" type="PPL",Australia PLACE country="AU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18443435" id="Pl-7" latLong="25.000°S 135.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The Home Office and police chiefs should instead tackle the possession of guns in criminal hands, said Prof Mauser, a member of the independent Fraser Institute in Canada .
column2: ,Canada PLACE country="CA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19437937" id="Pl-8" latLong="60.000°N 96.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: He has given evidence to select committees of the House of Commons and the Canadian Senate and predicted the escalation of gun crime on Britain 's streets.
column2: ,Britain PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-3" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Canadian PLACE country="CA" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19437937" id="Pl-9" latLong="60.000°N 96.000°W" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: His warning comes as gun crime incidents are averaging about 29 a day in England and Wales , more than twice the level of when the Labour Government came to power in 1997 .
column2: ,England PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17404382" id="Pl-11" latLong="53.000°N 2.000°W" state="GB-ENG" type="CIVIL",Wales PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389226" id="Pl-12" latLong="52.500°N 3.500°W" state="GB-WLS" type="CIVIL"

column1: In the past two years, there have been cases of schoolchildren and a baby, killed or injured by guns.
I believe that factors of political correctness are at work, he said.

Police crackdowns, Home Office initiatives and over-regulation of legally held weapons create froth and they may even fool the police themselves into believing they are doing something about gun crime.

Prof Mauser added: "The sad truth is that while the police officers are inspecting farmers' gun cabinets to see if they comply with regulations somewhere in the UK , someone, who has not filled in a firearms certificate form, will be smuggling a gun into the country or selling one to an inner city youth."
column2: ,UK PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-5" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY",country PLACE country="GB" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-13" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Recorded gun crime rose by three per cent to 10,590 incidents in the year to June .
Two-thirds of gun crime takes place in London , Birmingham and Manchester .

I would have shot the insurgent too.

I'm no fan of this war either, but it irks me to no end reading and listening to civilian opinions on how soldiers should conduct themselves in hostile war zones from their comfortable recliners.

To the world press and everyone else who despises the United States : You don't have to like our president or those operating this war, but get off the backs of the 18, 19 and 20 year-olds thrown into a situation you will never see or have to encounter.

column1: I've got too many friends in Iraq right now I want to see come home alive and well, and I will support them at every opportunity.
Not to be Ignored

2004-12-01T23:13:00 More than a few e-mails have come in wondering why I haven't remarked on the horrible hunting tragedy on Nov. 21 that left six people dead, and why I haven't updated the ASSAULT WEAPONS BAN COUNTER.
I didn't mean to wait this long and never intended to ignore the issue, but I have been extremely busy last week with Thanksgiving and everything that goes along with it.
This is problem that needs to be addressed.
But as for the assault weapons ban issue, the man accused of the brutal killings, Chai Vang of St. Paul , Minn , used a Russian -built Saiga 7.62 mm, SKS semiautomatic rifle.
column2: Minn PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:663849" id="Pl-2" latLong="46.250°N 94.250°W" state="US-MN" type="CIVIL",Russian PLACE country="RU" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17005945" id="Pl-4" latLong="60.000°N 100.000°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY",St. Paul PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:663851" id="Pl-1" latLong="44.944°N 93.093°W" state="US-MN" type="PPL"

column1: As this article points out, the SKS wasn't included on the list of banned weapons as part of the 10-year ban on certain "assault weapons" signed by President Clinton.
The ban expired in September and at the time of this posting, no one has been killed by any one of those weapons since the ban expired.
But let's talk about this case, as I'm sure discussions have started and many want stronger gun control because of this freak incident.
While the media use words like "military style," "assault" and "semiautomatic," the gun used in the slayings was not unlike a typical hunting rifle.
The SKS is a medium-powered carbine equipped with a 10-round magazine, just like the pistol I'm displaying in the photo on the left hand side of this blog.
Banned weapons had capacities of more than 10 rounds; so like my small 9mm, the SKS was not classified as an "assault" weapon.
So let's not center our discussion around the gun, let's talk about the person behind the trigger.
If convicted of the killings, Vang faces life in prison as Minnesota does not honor the death penalty.
column2: Minn PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:663849" id="Pl-2" latLong="46.250°N 94.250°W" state="US-MN" type="CIVIL",Minnesota PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:663849" id="Pl-3" latLong="46.250°N 94.250°W" state="US-MN" type="CIVIL"

column1: I look forward to Vang's conviction and I pray for the families of the victims.
What happened was indefensible and justice must be served.
Life-Saving Disease
2004-12-03T19:59:00 Here's an incredible story about an unsung hero until now.
From BBC News : A retired Italian doctor has revealed for the first time how he invented a fictitious disease which fooled the Nazis during World War II.
column2: Italian PLACE country="IT" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19880600" id="Pl-1" latLong="42.833°N 12.833°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The trick of prescribing Jews with a mysterious illness terrified the Nazis and saved 45 Roman Jews.
Dr Vittorio Sacerdoti has told his remarkable tale on the 60th anniversary of liberation of Rome .
column2: Rome PLACE country="IT" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19873307" id="Pl-2" latLong="41.900°N 12.483°E" state="IT-RM" type="PPLC"

column1: Just 28 years old at the time, he used courage and ingenuity to save 45 people from certain death.
As other Jews were being rounded up, Dr Sacerdoti admitted anyone who could reach the hospital as patients - and diagnosed them with a dangerous disease.
We would write on their medical forms that the patient was suffering from K Syndrome, he said.
We called it K after the German commander Kesserling - the Nazis thought it was cancer or tuberculosis, and they fled like rabbits.
column2: German PLACE country="DE" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:18224345" id="Pl-3" latLong="51.500°N 10.500°E" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: K Syndrome saved his cousin, Luciana Sacerdoti, who was just 10 years old.

The day the Nazis came to the hospital , someone came to our room and said: 'You have to cough, you have to cough a lot because they are afraid of the coughing, they don't want to catch an awful disease and they won't enter'.
It's Just Armor
2004-12-08T21:33:00 Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld took part in a Q&A with the troops today that was anything but cozy.
Disgruntled soldiers complained to Rumsfeld about long deployments and a lack of armored vehicles and other equipment.
From the Associated Press : "You go to war with the Army you have," Rumsfeld replied, "not the Army you might want or wish to have."
Spc.
Thomas Wilson had asked the defense secretary, "Why do we soldiers have to dig through local landfills for pieces of scrap metal and compromised ballistic glass to up-armor our vehicles?"
Shouts of approval and applause arose from the estimated 2,300 soldiers who had assembled to see Rumsfeld.
We do not have proper armored vehicles to carry with us north, Wilson, 31, of Nashville , Tenn. , concluded after asking again.
column2: Tenn. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1326873" id="Pl-2" latLong="35.750°N 86.250°W" state="US-TN" type="CIVIL",Nashville PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1653484" id="Pl-1" latLong="36.166°N 86.784°W" state="US-TN" type="PPLA"

column1: Wilson, an airplane mechanic whose unit, the 278th Regimental Combat Team of the Tennessee Army National Guard, is about to drive north into Iraq for a one-year tour of duty, put his finger on a problem that has bedeviled the Pentagon for more than a year.
column2: Tennessee PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1326873" id="Pl-3" latLong="35.750°N 86.250°W" predicative="true" state="US-TN" type="CIVIL",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-4" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Rarely, though, is it put so bluntly in a public forum.
Rumsfeld said the Army was sparing no expense or effort to acquire as many Humvees and other vehicles with extra armor as it can. What is more, he said, armor is not the savior some think it is.
You can have all the armor in the world on a tank and a tank can (still) be blown up, he said.
Can't say that's the most comforting answer.
Protect Yourself Not in San Francisco
column2: San Francisco PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:278593" id="Pl-1" latLong="37.775°N 122.418°W" state="CA" type="PPL"

column1: 2004-12-15T23:02:00 From the Associated Press : City residents will vote next year on a proposed weapons ban that would deny handguns to everyone except law enforcement officers, members of the military and security guards.

column1: If passed next November, residents would have 90 days to give up firearms they keep in their homes or businesses.
The proposal was immediately dismissed as illegal by a gun owners group.

Firearms would be allowed only for police officers, security guards, members of the military, and anyone else "actually employed and engaged in protecting and preserving property or life within the scope of his or her employment," according to the measure.
Gun Owners of California , a Sacramento -based lobbying group, quickly called the ban illegal.

column1: The amazing thing is they are going to turn San Francisco into ground zero for every criminal who wants to profit at their chosen profession, Paredes said.
column2: San Francisco PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:278593" id="Pl-3" latLong="37.775°N 122.418°W" state="CA" type="PPL"

column1: If approved, the weapons ban would take effect in January 2006.

Quote of the day: "Firearms would be allowed only for police officers, security guards, members of the military, and anyone else actually employed and engaged in protecting and preserving property or life within the scope of his or her employment."
So preserving property or life within the scope of self-defense and protection of the home is not allowed.
No thanks.

If the people vote for this measure it will be hard to sympathize with them when robbery and rape rates skyrocket, because burgulars will know homes are not guarded, and rapists will know the only thing stopping them from the victim they desire is their own inhibitions.

Woman Charged With Murder, Kidnapping Fetus-Thingy

2004-12-18T10:04:00 From the Associated Press : A baby girl who had been cut out of her mother's womb was found after a frantic search, and authorities arrested the woman they say strangled the mother and stole the child.
The baby was in good condition Saturday.
Lisa M. Montgomery, 36, of Melvern , Kan. , was arrested later Friday and charged with kidnapping resulting in death.
column2: Melvern PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:478555" id="Pl-3" latLong="38.507°N 95.638°W" state="US-KS" type="PPL",Kan. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:482813" id="Pl-2" latLong="38.500°N 98.500°W" state="US-KS" type="CIVIL"

column1: Bobbie Jo Stinnett, 23, was found Thursday in a pool of blood inside her small white home in Skidmore , a town in northwest Missouri . Stinnett, who was eight months pregnant, had earlier been talking with her mother on the phone, and hung up saying a woman she had chatted with online had just arrived at her door, authorities said.
column2: home PLACE country="US" form="NOM" id="Pl-115" state="US-MO" type="FAC",Missouri PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780791" id="Pl-6" latLong="38.250°N 92.500°W" mod="NW" state="US-MO" type="CIVIL",town PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:727506" id="Pl-7" latLong="40.289°N 95.081°W" state="US-MO" type="PPL",Skidmore PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:727506" id="Pl-5" latLong="40.289°N 95.081°W" state="US-MO" type="PPL"

column1: U.S. Attorney Todd Graves said Montgomery contacted Stinnett through an online message board, and authorities zeroed in on her using computer forensics.
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-8" predicative="true" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Montgomery was seeking to buy a dog from Stinnett, who raised rat terriers, he said.
According to the criminal complaint, Montgomery traveled about 40 miles to Topeka , Kan. , on Thursday to go shopping.
column2: Topeka PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:486477" id="Pl-4" latLong="39.048°N 95.678°W" state="US-KS" type="PPLA",Kan. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:482813" id="Pl-2" latLong="38.500°N 98.500°W" state="US-KS" type="CIVIL"

column1: Her husband received a call from her saying she had gone into labor and given birth.
The next day, authorities say, Montgomery confessed that she strangled Stinnett from behind, cut her open, removed the baby and cut her umbilical cord.
I don't understand how we can call this fetus-thing that was ripped from a mother's womb a "child" or "girl" in a society that sanctions partial-birth abortion.
If you can't charge someone for killing a fetus via abortion during the eighth month, then surely you can't make a big deal about a woman who kidnapped a fetus that survived the knifing.
On a less-sarcastic note, I pray for the family of the 23-year-old woman.
No one should have to die because some crazy nut wanted a child and decided to kill for it.
If there's any good news in this story, it's that Victoria Jo will live on and carry her mother's memory.
Question for the pro-choicers: Being that it isn't yet the ninth month, can we still charge the killer with kidnapping?

Bush administration quietly stops destroying chemical and biological weapons

Mon, 24 Jan 2005 05:40:37 -0600 Bush administration quietly stops destroying chemical and biological weapons Unnoticed by anyone else, the Bush administration has quietly ditched programs to destroy America 's biggest-in-the-world stockpile of chemical and biological weapons.
column2: America PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-1" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Eight places in the US are used to stockpile chemical weapons -- including blister agents, riot agents, and the dreaded nerve agents.
column2: US PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-2" type="COUNTRY"

column1: In these eight locations, hundreds of thousands of artillery rounds, bombs, and rockets are stacked in both open and bunker storage, some of them leaking their contents and all of the very deadly.

Storage locations include: -- Anniston Army Depot, Anniston , AL -- Rocky Mountain Arsenal, Pueblo , CO -- Bluegrass Army Depot, Lexington , KY -- Aberdeen Proving Grounds, MD -- Toelle Army Depot, Toelle , UT (the granddaddy of them all) Destruction is underway in Anniston where the Dept of Defense built and is operating an incinerator to burn weapons located there.

column1: Jack Welch seeks details on estranged wife's work in divorce case
Retired General Electric Co. Chairman Jack Welch is seeking work-related documents of his estranged wife in his high-stakes divorce case.

The Welches disclosed their plans to divorce a year ago, shortly after Suzy Wetlaufer _ then editor of the Harvard Business Review _ revealed she had become romantically involved with Welch while working on a story about him.
In court papers filed this week in state Supreme Court in New York , Welch requested a deposition next month of David Heleniak, a senior partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling in New York .
column2: New York PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:1780796" id="Pl-5" latLong="43.000°N 75.500°W" state="US-NY" type="CIVIL",state PLACE country="US" form="NOM" gazref="IGDB:1780796" id="Pl-4" latLong="43.000°N 75.500°W" predicative="true" state="US-NY" type="CIVIL"

column1: He also wants to subpoena all documents maintained in Jane Beasley Welch's personnel file by Shearman & Sterling, a prestigious corporate law firm where she worked before she married Welch.

Welch specifically is seeking performance evaluations, correspondence between his estranged wife and partners while she worked at the law firm's office in London , and documents related to her prospects of becoming a partner.
column2: office PLACE country="GB" form="NOM" id="Pl-131" state="GB-ENG" type="FAC",London PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17398111" id="Pl-6" latLong="51.500°N 0.117°W" state="GB-ENG" type="PPLC"

column1: Welch also wants details on Jane Beasley Welch's salary, benefits, retirement plan and other compensation paid to her.
Michael York, one of Jack Welch's attorneys, called the move routine.
A judge ruled in February that depositions in the divorce case will remain confidential.
Earlier documents in the case have included embarrassing details about perks Welch received as part of his retirement package from GE at a time when corporate scandals were sparking outrage.
The court order was requested by Jack Welch's attorney, Daniel K. Webb, who said Welch would likely be asked about his business dealings, his health and entries in his personal diary.
Webb also said details of the breakdowns of the Welches' previous marriages were likely to come up, and cited reports of alleged extramarital affairs by both.
Welch has previously failed in an attempt to temporarily seal a financial affidavit.

That document detailed monthly outlays of some $51,000 for upkeep on a half-dozen houses scattered from Massachusetts to Florida , more than $52,000 for gifts and nearly $9,000 for food and drink, among other expenses.
column2: Massachusetts PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:607926" id="Pl-7" latLong="42.250°N 71.500°W" state="US-MA" type="CIVIL",Florida PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:295478" id="Pl-8" latLong="28.750°N 82.500°W" state="FL" type="CIVIL"

column1: First relief convoy arrives in Iraq  as allies struggle to clear the
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-1" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: UMM QASR , Iraq (AP) The first sizable relief convoy arrived in Iraq during a sandstorm Wednesday as allied forces struggled to clear the way for more aid shipments, using dolphins to remove mines from waterways and hunting Iraqi fighters around the port of Umm Qasr .
column2: UMM QASR PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-19" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL",Umm Qasr PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-39" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-16" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-14" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: Three days after U.S. President George W. Bush promised ``massive amounts'' of humanitarian aid, seven large, battered tractor-trailers arrived in Umm Qasr carrying food and water donated by Kuwaitis.
column2: Umm Qasr PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-39" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL",Kuwaiti PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-17" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY",U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-31" type="COUNTRY",Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-18" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The convoy was escorted by U.S. soldiers.
column2: U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-31" type="COUNTRY"

column1: ``We planned for 30 trucks but we only got seven loaded because of the severe sandstorm,'' said E.J. Russell of the Humanitarian Operations Center, a joint U.S. - Kuwaiti agency.
column2: Kuwaiti PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-17" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY",U.S. PLACE country="US" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:840" id="Pl-31" type="COUNTRY",Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-18" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The storm cut visibility to about 100 yards (91 meters).
Hundreds of cases of water were stacked on three of the trucks.
The rest carried boxes of tuna, crackers, sweets and other food.

As the trucks lumbered past blasted buildings on the Iraq - Kuwait border, an Iraqi boy of about 10 pointed to his mouth and shouted ``Eat, eat!'' People lined up along the streets, giving thumbs-up signs to the aid convoy as it rolled by and begging for food and cigarettes.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-16" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-14" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Kuwait PLACE country="KW" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:19210228" id="Pl-18" latLong="29.500°N 47.750°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: After days of fierce fighting that shut down the city of Umm Qasr , Iraqi youths cheered and swarmed British troops as they handed out yellow meal packets and bottles of water Wednesday.
column2: Umm Qasr PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-39" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL",British PLACE country="GB" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:17389505" id="Pl-37" latLong="54.000°N 4.000°W" type="COUNTRY",Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-16" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",Iraqi PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-14" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY"

column1: The troops, already in the city, were not part of the aid convoy.
`` Umm Qasr is now secure _ as a port and as a town,'' said Brig.
column2: Umm Qasr PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-39" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL",town PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-33" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL"

column1: Jim Dutton of the Royal Marines.
The town 's deepwater port, the only one in Iraq , is essential for any relief effort.
column2: Iraq PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16897518" id="Pl-16" latLong="33.000°N 44.000°E" type="COUNTRY",town PLACE country="IQ" form="NAM" gazref="IGDB:16887773" id="Pl-33" latLong="30.034°N 47.929°E" state="BA" type="PPL"

column1: Report: Toefting drops appeal of assault conviction, will do jail
COPENHAGEN , Denmark (AP) Former Danish international Stig Toefting dropped his appeal of an assault conviction and will serve a four-month jail sentence, Denmark 's TV2 reported Monday.

Earlier this month, Toefting said English Premier League club Bolton let him go so he could prepare for the appeal.

column1: Some frontline units went on heightened alert against the threat of chemical weapons, ordered to wear rubber boots and suits despite temperatures that soared into the 90s.

column1: ``We mowed down'' the attackers, said Lt. Col. B.P. McCoy.

Despite declarations that more tough fighting lies ahead, the top U.S. military official indicated there may not be an all-out battle for Baghdad . Gen. Richard Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, suggested isolating members of the old regime in the capital _ cut off from the rest of the country _ while an ``interim administration'' is put in place to begin work on a postwar government.

column1: The Navy was searching for the pilot Thursday.

Iraqis had held the town for 13 years.
